chunks.chunk_text: Hello Hello你現在收聽的是同情選語15 Minutes.Today我是John老師在這裡跟你分享我們15 Minutes今天正式升級為2.0啦我們把過去同情家族所提的回饋以及建議在我們的節目名稱以及內容做了些許調整為了就是讓節目更聚焦單元與內容更明確引入更廣泛的專業講師群與主題拉近你與英語的距離從即日起

chunks.chunk_text: 《每日英語更讀》現在是叫《國際時事更讀》過去的精選詞彙播客現在為《15 Minutes.英語咖啡館》希望我們新的調整會再次強化你的自然富力、音聽與說的計戰力That's not all過幾天我們也會透過口播與IG、FB公告VIP訂閱制的啟動還有相關找鳥創始VIP會員的優惠敬請期待這次不要再漏了訊息喔

chunks.chunk_text: International unity in spaceThe successful docking of a U.S. astronaut and Russian cosmonauts at the ISS underscores how space exploration promotes international collaboration transcending geopolitical tensions on EarthCosmic camaraderieIn space, astronauts and cosmonauts demonstrate a unique bond, taking care of each other regardless of their national backgrounds

chunks.chunk_text: 2 Russian cosmonauts and a U.S. astronaut successfully docked with the International Space Station ISS on Friday, despite heightened tensions between Moscow and Washington due to the Ukraine conflictThe journey commenced when Roscosmos cosmonauts Oleg Konono-Nikol and Nikolai Chub along with NASA astronaut Laurel O'Hara

chunks.chunk_text: board the Soyuz MS-24 spacecraftJust three hours later, the crew safely arrived at the ISS where they joined three Russians, two Americans, a Japanese astronaut and a representative from the European Space AgencyThis collaborative effort stands in stark contrast to the deteriorating U.S.-Russia relations

chunks.chunk_text: triggered by Moscow's actions in Ukraine last yearDuring a pre-flight press conference, Oleg Konono-Nikol emphasized the unique camaraderie experienced in space, stating unlike on Earth, cosmonauts and astronauts genuinely look out for each otherHe highlighted the strong bonds formed in space where communication is essential, saying we hear each other there and we understand each other

chunks.chunk_text: were scheduled for a year-long stay on the ISS,O'Hara, aged 40, was planned to spend six months in spaceThis mission marked their first journey into space for both O'Hara and Chub, with Chub revealing that traveling to space had been his lifelong dreamThe trio succeeded Russian cosmonauts Dmitry Petilin and Sergey Prokopyev, as well as NASA astronaut Frank Rubin
